I just want to kind of jump in the high-level portions of this and just kind of start off and let you all know that this was really a team and collective effort led by basically citywide Recruiters and Department heads across the city.

When we got the request a few months back, the idea of it was really to hear our Stakeholders, get an idea of what are the challenges, what are the high-level priority positions that we're having challenges for.

So we as Recruiters across the city, we meet every other Thursday, and we really focus in on some of those trends, what are each Department seeing, what are the Heartburns around different positions, what are some of the challenges, how we can come together as a recruiting network to support each other.
Postings, whether it be posting jobs on Linkedin or just sharing our network.

From those meetings, we found out it was the--the best practice was to do a survey, and we surveyed all the citywide Recruiters across the city for each Department and really got feedback from them on some of those high-level critical roles to fill.

About five days later we called a meeting with the Department heads across the city and had a discussion of what are some of the trends they are seeing within their departments and how can we come together and really focus on this thing.
So it wasn't just a Seattle Department of human resources decision.
It was a team decision.
And you know we really kind of came to the conclusion in regards to the citywide hiring and said what that would look like for the future.
I just wanted to kind of go over to set the table for everybody, but also do kind of a little bit of a high-level review of all those positions that came in hand.
So like I said, we reached out to the city departments, identified Hard-To-Fill positions and the fact that it was Impacting the city's ability to higher talent.
At the hr we found many factors that affect the ability to attract full-time workers.
Most are full-time benefits and from temporary to full-time employment.
We felt like the temporary pool was the most diverse pool but we really take advantage of to fill different gaps in different areas to help support staffing across the city.
Hiring incentives to what we came to the conclusion are more of a short-term strategy to attract more applicants.
The city began offering incentives in 2021 for certain public safety positions.
Seattle police Department did not increase an increase in hiring since implementing a hiring incentives in October of 2021.
The community safety and communications center however did see an increase in candidates entering the hiring process since the implementation of an incentive in October of 2021.
Based on the limited time frame for the incentive, though, there wasn't enough time to get conclusive data.

In addition, based on the feedback we received, like I said, we did our road show from the city Department, so largest barrier to attract and promoting and retaining talent is our compensation program.
That's where a majority of our employees who have worked for the city get stuck, in the classification system.
Just to kind of give you an idea around that, our class specifications are from 1990.
They have not been updated since 1990.

So give you an example, if a person is trying to hire, say they've been with the city in an accounting position for maybe 15 or 20 years, we feel like transferable skills and the fact their work experience can substitute, a lot of times, for education.
With this certain classification, if a person is trying to go for a senior accounting position, they have to have 24 hours of semester work.

And, you know, we've had employees get kind of stuck in those type of positions and Unfortunately they're unable to advance their career, which really impacts departments to sometimes be able to see those promotions for employees.
About two years ago before the pandemic, we did a citywide job fair and we really focused in on just city employees and we invited all our temporary employees.

And we had a huge, huge turnout, and the exciting part about it, we had folks that were able to get connected up that were in those temporary positions for a while, connected up in the full-time opportunities.

And we found out there was a lot of, like I said, barriers within those prospects that I think if we put our efforts and resources in looking at some of the class Specs in the positions that I will talk about, there's some ways where we can knock down some of those challenges.
So within our retention challenges, we created a recruitment challenges survey.
I'll give you a list of the following positions that were listed as critical city business needs.
Carpenter, plumber, truck driver, Rec attendants, civil engineer, police officers, Hvac technicians, Cashiers, engineers public safety auditor, veterinary, and 911 Dispatchers.

The lack of qualified candidates was a primary factor identified for these Hard-To-Fill roles and survey once again came back around to minimum qualifications, constraints in the city's outdated classification system that crosses those barriers to retain, promote, and really hire internal and external women and Bipoc into the city.
So really kind of with Sbhr, we took an idea and looked at some of the trends and some of the other things that really impacted, you know, some of those challenges.
So I go back to class Specs.
You know, as far as the job duties described in these job classifications, they don't always pertain to the work that needs to be completed by today's city work force.

Updating the city's 30-year-old classification system I think will improve the city's ability to attract entry level skilled trades and other positions with transferable skills and lived experience can be substituted for education requirements for multiple years of work and experience.

The task to review the job classification system is definitely significant, but it is an update to the system and even if we start out with maybe 20 or 30 classifications that are critical roles and we're not seeing the talent come through in the challenges of recruiting, maybe we focus in on those first.
So this was really kind of the conclusion in regards to the hiring incentive and really some pros and Cons.
Offering a hiring incentive is a short-time strategy like was mentioned earlier.
You know, of course you'll probably get a person to accept the offer, but in the King County area, other local jurisdictions have been offering similar hiring incentives.

While have departments in the city of Seattle have observed a clear and positive benefit, this must be weighed against other situations where this can approach and really has inherent drawbacks and equity issues for both employers and employees.
So, for example, once an employee is on board, even a structured signing bonus with additional PAYOUT has limited impact on retention.
The money is a one-time quick fix which may not address competitive wages.
Lack of opportunity to develop skills and promotion.
-- employees promoted internally or already working in the job can really feel undervalued or Underappreciated when the financial package does not match what external recruits receive.

And especially coming out of the pandemic and retaining our employees and making sure they're not leaving us for other opportunities and with the current city employees identified with the Hard-To-Fill positions it's really hard to maintain our front line employees and really focus on taking care of them.
So I go back to those really things about the critical roles and about the hiring incentive.
